questions.text: A 20 year old boy reports to clinic within 2 hours of acquiring a clean wound without laceration. He had received TT vaccination last at 10 years of age. What will be your advise as prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
For a 20-year-old who presents with a clean wound and had their last tetanus toxoid (TT) vaccination 10 years ago, the recommended prophylaxis is as follows:

  • If the last dose of TT was given within the past 5 years, no additional dose is needed.
  • If it has been more than 5 years since the last dose, a booster dose of TT is recommended for clean wounds.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Since this patient received the TT vaccine 10 years ago and had a clean wound, a booster dose is appropriate Single dose of TT

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-05, Page number.:358-362.

questions.text: Vaccine derived poliovirus (VDPV) is related to:
questions.solution:
Vaccine-derived poliovirus (VDPV) is related to: b. P2

VDPV arises from the Sabin oral polio vaccine (OPV) strains. Specifically, VDPV is related to the P2 strain of poliovirus.

VDPV is a rare but significant issue related to polio eradication efforts and requires ongoing monitoring and response.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- VDPV arises from the Sabin oral polio vaccine (OPV) strains

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-05, Page number.:244-248.

questions.text: Both increase in number and maturation, the correct statement is:
questions.solution:
In the context of vector-borne diseases and their transmission:

  • Propagative: Refers to processes where the pathogen multiplies within the vector but does not undergo any developmental changes.
  • Cyclo-propagative: Involves both multiplication and developmental changes of the pathogen within the vector.
  • Cyclo-developmental: Refers to developmental changes that the pathogen undergoes in the vector without multiplication.

Reference: Cyclo-propagative: Involves both multiplication and developmental changes of the pathogen within the vector

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-05,Page number:305-310.

questions.text: A 17 year old boy was brought in the emergency department with symptoms of acute encephalopathy. He was admitted in icu , initial investigation revealed that his liver had undergone fatty degeneration. His father gave a history of dew drop rash mostly on the flexor surfaces of his body and tablet combiflam was given by his father to decrease fever what is the proper diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms described—acute encephalopathy, fatty degeneration of the liver, and a history of dew drop rash predominantly on the flexor surfaces—are consistent with: c. Chicken pox

Chickenpox (varicella) often presents with a characteristic rash that starts as small red spots and evolves into fluid-filled vesicles ("dew drop on a rose petal").

The rash commonly appears on flexor surfaces, and complications such as encephalopathy and liver issues can occur, especially if the patient has been given certain medications like ibuprofen (Combiflam), which is not recommended for chickenpox due to the risk of severe complications.

Here’s the symptoms and pathognomonic signs for each of the diseases:

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Chickenpox (varicella) often presents with a characteristic rash that starts as small red spots and evolves into fluid-filled vesicles ("dew drop on a rose petal").

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-05,Page number.:161-172.

questions.text: Mother brought her child for measles vaccination to a clinic. Health worker told her to purchase diluent from the market as it was out of stock at that time. What could be that diluent?
questions.solution:
The diluent used for reconstituting the measles vaccine is distilled water. Therefore, the correct answer is: b. Distilled water

  • common vaccines and their diluents used for reconstitution:

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The diluent used for reconstituting the measles vaccine is distilled water.

Reference: Immunization_Handbook_for_Medical_Officers 2017, MOHFW, GOI, unit number-04, Page Number – 19-26 .

questions.text: There is an outbreak of encephalitis in a community of Gorakhpur district of UP. According to the universal immunization schedule, the route of administration of vaccine for the likely infection is?
questions.solution:
The likely infection in the Gorakhpur district is Japanese Encephalitis (JE), which is common in that area. According to the Universal Immunization Programme (UIP) in India, the vaccine used for Japanese Encephalitis is a Live and subcutaneous.


KEY TAKEAWAYS- The vaccine used for Japanese Encephalitis is a Live and subcutaneous.

Reference: Immunization_Handbook_for_Medical_Officers 2017,MOHFW,GOI, unit number.-02 & FAQs , Page Number –20 & 290.

questions.text: A 27 year old patient was diagnosed to have leprosy and started multi-bacillary drug therapy. Six weeks later he developed pain in nerves and redness and swelling of skin lesions. Management include all except?
questions.solution:
In the management of a leprosy patient who develops pain in the nerves, redness, and swelling of skin lesions (which are signs of a leprosy reaction or Type 1/Type 2 lepra reaction), the correct management approach includes all of the following except: a. Stop anti-leprosy drug

The correct management typically includes:

  • Systemic steroids to reduce inflammation.
  • Rest of the affected limb to prevent further nerve damage.
  • Analgesics to manage pain.

Stopping anti-leprosy drugs is not recommended during a lepra reaction.

The reaction is a part of the immune response, not a side effect of the drugs. Therefore, the multidrug therapy (MDT) should be continued while managing the reaction with supportive treatments.

Management approach for Type 1 and Type 2 Lepra reactions:

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Stopping anti-leprosy drugs is not recommended during a lepra reaction.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-05,Page number.:366-372.

questions.text: The causative organism of smallpox was a virus called?
questions.solution:
The causative organism of smallpox is the Variola virus, which belongs to the Poxviridae family.

 Virus Structure

  • The Variola virus is a double-stranded DNA virus.
  • It has a large, brick-shaped structure, with a genome that encodes for around 200 proteins, making it one of the largest and most complex viruses known.
  • It replicates in the cytoplasm of infected cells, which is unusual for a DNA virus (most DNA viruses replicate in the nucleus).

 Transmission

  • Smallpox spreads primarily through respiratory droplets (person-to-person transmission), but it can also spread through direct contact with infected bodily fluids or contaminated objects.
  • The incubation period ranges from 7 to 17 days, during which no symptoms are present, but the infected person can become contagious.

Infection and Symptoms

  • After infection, the virus initially multiplies in the lymphoid tissues, then spreads through the bloodstream.
  • It causes symptoms such as high fever, malaise, and a characteristic progressive skin rash that turns into pus-filled sores, eventually scarring the skin.

Vaccine Development

  • The smallpox vaccine was one of the first vaccines ever developed, using the Vaccinia virus, a related but less harmful poxvirus. This vaccine led to the successful eradication of smallpox globally.

Common diseases and their causative organisms:

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The causative organism of smallpox is the Variola virus, which belongs to the Poxviridae family.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-05, Page number.:159-170.

questions.text: "Hundred days cough" term is used for?
questions.solution:
The term “Hundred days cough” is used for C. Pertussis (whooping cough).

Pertussis is a highly contagious respiratory disease caused by the bacterium Bordetella pertussis. It is characterized by severe coughing spells that can last for weeks or even months, hence the term "hundred days cough.

  • The term "Hundred Days Cough" refers to Pertussis, also known as whooping cough, which is caused by the bacterium Bordetella pertussis.
  • The disease is characterized by prolonged coughing fits that can last for weeks or even months, often up to 100 days. During these fits, patients may experience a distinctive "whooping" sound when they inhale, especially in children.

Incorrect Options: Other options like chronic bronchitis, measles, and chronic allergic alveolitis do not typically involve prolonged coughing spells in the same way.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The term “Hundred days cough” is used for C. Pertussis (whooping cough).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-05, Page number.:181-183.

questions.text: The extrinsic incubation period of vivax malaria is about?
questions.solution:
The extrinsic incubation period of vivax malaria (the time it takes for the malaria parasite to develop in the mosquito after it has ingested blood from an infected human) is typically about 10 days, depending on environmental factors like temperature.

The correct answer is C. 10 days.

The extrinsic incubation period is a critical phase for malaria transmission, as it determines when the mosquito becomes capable of infecting humans after taking an infected blood meal.

KEY TAKEAWAYS- The extrinsic incubation period of vivax malaria (the time it takes for the malaria parasite to develop in the mosquito after it has ingested blood from an infected human) is typically about 10 days, depending on environmental factors like temperature.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-05,Page number.:301-305.

choices.text: Adult filariae dwell in human tissues and live for several years
Agents of lymphatic filariasis reside in lymphatic vessels and lymph nodes
Female worms produce microfilariae which circulate in the blood
Female worm lays up to 500 eggs which convert into larvae in 1 week

questions.text: True about life cycle of filariasis is Except ?
questions.solution:
The statement that is not true about the life cycle of filariasis is:

D. Female worm lays up to 500 eggs which convert into larvae in 1 week.

Explanation:

  • Adult filariae dwell in human tissues and live for several years: This is true. Adult filariae can live for several years in human tissues, such as lymphatic vessels or subcutaneous tissues.
  • Agents of lymphatic filariasis reside in lymphatic vessels and lymph nodes: This is true. The causative agents of lymphatic filariasis (such as Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, and Brugia timori) reside in the lymphatic system.
  • Female worms produce microfilariae which circulate in the blood: This is true. Female filarial worms produce microfilariae (immature larvae), which circulate in the bloodstream and can be picked up by mosquitoes.
  • Female worm lays up to 500 eggs which convert into larvae in 1 week: This is false. Female filarial worms do not lay eggs. Instead, they produce microfilariae directly into the blood or tissues, which then develop into larvae within the mosquito vector. The development of these microfilariae into larvae happens inside the mosquito, not in eggs.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Female filarial worms do not lay eggs. Instead, they produce microfilariae directly into the blood or tissues, which then develop into larvae within the mosquito vector. The development of these microfilariae into larvae happens inside the mosquito, not in eggs.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-05,Page no.: 316-320.

choices.text: Major public health problem with presence of multiple serotypes of virus
Dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) an emerging problem with frequent cyclical outbreaks
Expansion of territory under the effect of dengue
Aedes albopictus is principal vector during the epidemics

questions.text: All of the following statements about dengue in India are correct EXCEPT ?
questions.solution:
The statement that is not correct about dengue in India is:

D. Aedes albopictus is principal vector during the epidemics.

  • A. Major public health problem with presence of multiple serotypes of virus: This is correct. Dengue is a significant public health issue in India, and the virus exists in four distinct serotypes (DENV-1, DENV-2, DENV-3, and DENV-4).
  • B. Dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) an emerging problem with frequent cyclical outbreaks: This is correct. Dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) is a severe form of dengue that has become a significant concern, with cyclical outbreaks occurring in various regions.
  • C. Expansion of territory under the effect of dengue: This is correct. The geographical range of dengue has expanded over the years, with outbreaks occurring in new areas due to factors like climate change and urbanization.
  • D. Aedes albopictus is principle vector during the epidemics: This is incorrect.The principal vector for dengue during epidemics in India is Aedes aegypti, not Aedes albopictus. While Aedes albopictus can also act as a vector, Aedes aegypti is the primary mosquito responsible for dengue transmission.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-The principal vector for dengue during epidemics in India is Aedes aegypti, not Aedes albopictus

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-05, Page no.: 290-295.

choices.text: Transmitted through airborne droplets from an infected human
Most common source is bite of an infected flea
Case fatality rate is lower in this type than bubonic plague

questions.text: True about primary pneumonic plague is
questions.solution:
The true statement about primary pneumonic plague is:A. Transmitted through airborne droplets from an infected human.

  • A. Transmitted through airborne droplets from an infected human: This is correct. Primary pneumonic plague is an infection of the lungs that can be transmitted from person to person through respiratory droplets, making it highly contagious.
  • B. Most common source is bite of an infected flea: This is incorrect for primary pneumonic plague. The primary source of pneumonic plague is not flea bites but rather direct transmission from respiratory droplets of an infected person. Flea bites are more commonly associated with bubonic plague.
  • C. Man is a deadened infection: This is incorrect. In pneumonic plague, humans are not "dead-end" hosts; they can transmit the disease to others. Dead-end hosts do not contribute to further transmission.
  • D. Case fatality rate is lower in this type than bubonic plague: This is incorrect. Primary pneumonic plague generally has a higher case fatality rate compared to bubonic plague, especially if not treated promptly with appropriate antibiotics.

Primary Pneumonic Plague:

KEY TAKEAWAYS- Primary pneumonic plague is a severe and highly contagious form of plague that affects the lungs and can spread from person to person through respiratory droplets.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-05,Page no.:340-344.

choices.text: Transmitted by several species of hard ticks
Does occur to other species (extra human) as well
Seen exclusively in Japan and other Asia pacific countries

questions.text: Which of the following statement about the kyasanur forest disease (KFD) is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) is:

D. Seen exclusively in Japan and other Asia pacific countries

  • Disease of viral etiology: This is correct. Kyasanur Forest Disease is caused by a virus belonging to the Flavivirus
  • B. Transmitted by several species of hard ticks: This is correct. KFD is transmitted primarily by the Haemaphysalisspinigera tick, but other hard tick species may also be involved.
  • C. Does occur to other species (extra human) as well: This is correct. KFD affects not only humans but also a variety of wildlife, including monkeys, which are often a reservoir for the virus.
  • D. Seen exclusively in Japan and other Asia pacific countries: This is incorrect. Kyasanur Forest Disease is primarily found in India, particularly in the state of Karnataka. It is not seen exclusively in Japan or other Asia Pacific countries.

Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD):

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Kyasanur Forest Disease is a tick-borne viral infection with significant public health implications, especially in the regions where it is endemic. The disease is primarily spread through tick bites and can also affect wildlife, which serves as a reservoir for the virus.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, chapter-05,Page no.:406-410.

choices.text: Direct contact with biological secretions of infected persons
Healthcare workers can be infected while attending patients
Bite of ticks and mites which have earlier bitten the infected person

questions.text: All are true about the transmission of Ebola virus EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
The statement that is not true about the transmission of Ebola virus is:

D. Bite of ticks and mites which have earlier bitten the infected person

  • Direct contact with biological secretions of infected persons: This is true. Ebola virus is transmitted through direct contact with the blood, body fluids, or secretions of infected individuals.
  • B. Handling ill/dead chimpanzees (infected): This is true. Ebola virus can be transmitted through handling or coming into contact with the body fluids or tissues of infected animals, including chimpanzees and other primates.
  • C. Healthcare workers can be infected while attending patients: This is true. Health care workers are at high risk of infection if they come into contact with infected patients' body fluids without proper protective measures.
  • D. Bite of ticks and mites which have earlier bitten the infected person: This is not true. The Ebola virus is not transmitted by ticks or mites. Its primary mode of transmission is through direct contact with bodily fluids of infected individuals.

KEY TAKEAWAYS-Ebola virus is primarily transmitted through direct contact with the bodily fluids of infected individuals or animals. It is not spread through casual contact or by vectors such as ticks or mites.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition,chapter-05,Page no.:406-410.
